utterances: Don't even go that far yet.
Let's talk about Joe Biden.
He's the sitting incumbent vice president.
You usually have a leg up on the nomination.
But Joe Biden, of course, will be 73 years old, and there's a lot of young folks in the Democratic Party like Andrew Cuomo, the governor of New York.
Andrew Cuomo.
Yes.
Like Martin O'Malley, the governor of Maryland.
Like Mark Warner, the senator from Virginia.
So look.
Hillary Clinton may have the leg up in 2016.
If it's not Hillary Clinton, I would suspect it's a wide open field.
So pretty good bench for both parties for 2016.
There is, absolutely.
And you could ask the question, after two terms of a Democratic president, is the nation ready to switch and go to the Republican Party?
But not if they keep losing female voters, not if they lose Latino voters.
And other minorities.
And other minorities and young voters.
A lot of young voters did not go for the Republican ticket once again.
So the Republicans certainly know where they went wrong in 2012.
The Democrats certainly know the opportunities they have in 2016.
And we'll see what happens from then.
That's NPR's political junkie Ken Rudin.
Ken, we will talk to you in 2016.
No. I'll talk to you before then.
OK.
Thanks.
It doesn't happen often in Chicago, but residents will soon have to get used to having a mayor not named Daley.
Mayor Richard M.
Daley says he will not seek a seventh term for the office he's held for the last 21 years, an office his father, Richard J.
Daley, also held for 21 years.
The announcement dramatically shifts a political landscape in Chicago.
And there is talk that a big name in the White House might go home to run for the job.
NPR's David Schaper reports.
In most cities, when a politician announces he's running for something, it's news, sometimes big news.
In Chicago, when someone named Daley announces he's leaving an office some would say he claimed by birthright, it's huge news, a political tsunami.
Mayor RICHARD M.
DALEY (Chicago): Today, I'm announcing that I will not seek a seventh term as mayor of the city of Chicago.

Standing with his family in a hastily called news conference, Daley, the longest serving big city mayor in the country, stunned Chicago by saying it's simply time, time for him and time for the city to move on.
The truth is that I've been thinking about this for the last several months.
In the last several weeks I've been increasingly comfortable with my decision.
It just feels right.
Daley often has said he doesn't want to be mayor for life, though many in Chicago thought he would be.
Some close to him have said Daley thought the stress of the job may have contributed to his father's death while in office in 1976 and that he didn't want the same to happen to him.
And the 68-year-old Daley's decision comes as his wife Maggie battles cancer and has had recent setbacks.

But it also comes with the city's bank account deep in the red and no easy ways to erase the record $655 million budget deficit, and all kinds of other problems that would have been big Chicago potholes on Daley's road to re-election.

Street gangs terrorize some city neighborhoods, there's a shortage of jobs and affordable housing, and federal corruption investigations at city hall, plus Daley's autocratic style, all have contributed to Mayor Daley's approval rating among city voters dropping like a Chicago thermometer in January.
But if any of that influenced Daley's decision to walk away from a job he professes to love, he didn't say so in his brief statement Tuesday afternoon.
In the end, this is a personal decision - no more, no less.
This is a political bombshell.
Cook County Clerk David Orr.
Obviously this town is so used to Daleys as mayor, and it really kind of puts everything up in the air.

Orr says he's not really thinking about running for a job he once held for about a week on an interim basis after the death of Harold Washington in 1987, but like many Chicago politicians, he's not ruling it out.
The lack of food, the exposure to the elements, to the sun during the day, to the cold at night and rain during the day, all of these can combine to create truly fatal circumstances.
From Jersey City, Matthew Daniel (ph) had these thoughts about her misunderstanding.
That's what we get, he writes, for putting more money into missiles than civics classes.
(Soundbite of people chanting)
We got a lot of letters appreciative of our series on The Source Family.
This was the 1970s spiritual commune led by a guy named Father Yod.
He formed it in Los Angeles and then moved to Hawaii.
Right, but one listener who lived near The Source Compound on Oahu, wasn't so happy to be reminded of them.
Carlotta Moody (ph), who now lives in Edmond, Oklahoma, says they irritated neighbors with their early morning chanting.
She says they didn't believe in diapers, and folks didn't appreciate mothers nursing their babies on the bus and in stores around town.
She concludes, we were all very happy to see them move away.
OK, well, if you have thoughts, suggestions, comments, criticisms, whatever, please write us.
Go to our website, npr.org, click on the contact us link.
And maybe next time, we'll read your letter.
Steve Proffitt, thank you.
You're welcome, Madeleine.
Back now with DAY TO DAY.
Contributing writer Marcos McPeek Villatoro has been thinking mythic thoughts.
He tried to challenge his teenage son in an athletic contest.
Oh, Marcos.
I ran across the tae kwon do mats like Mercury sent on a mission from Zeus or merely heading to the bathroom - I leapt.
As I came down in that slow motion oh-my-God-second knowing that something had gone terribly wrong, I thought of one man - Oedipus.
I fell in a heap of 45-year-old manhood - a pillar in the great foundation had collapsed.
That crack shot its way into every corner and crevice of the school.
The snap roused the harmonious oooh out of all the other students and then, oh man, that ain't good, out of Mae(ph) - the Vietnamese-American girl in the purple belt.
My toes had hooked the second of two high-punching pads now used by our teacher Frank as jumping obstacles.
Some chose oh so wisely not to try it once it got to 10 feet.
My son David stepped up.
Move it a little more, he said to Frank.
Gazelle-like, that 13-year-old body glided up over and touched down on the other side.
I was up.
I jumped, a water buffalo, heaving itself over a crevice.
I knocked the pad down, but I landed on my feet.
Let me try again, Frank.
And there it was, Oedipus.
All this was my son's fault, you see?
Over in the corner stood an old man with a white beard and round spectacles, chewing on a cigar and saying, don't do it, man, ain't worth it.
Let your boy kill you.
But I couldn't see Freud.
All I saw was that son of mine, all glisteny with youth and manhood, and by God, I'm going to make it.
Oedipus Rex, crashes and burns.
At home, while dropping my ball of a foot in a bucket of ice, David asks, how's it going?
Like you care.
But I say, oh fine, just fine.
His mother walks in and tosses his hair and says, that was a heck of a jump, and he smiled, as though, he did it all for her.
I never saw this one coming, empathizing with the old king.
I get it.
The boy has to beat the dad.
A man's reach should exceed his grasp, right?
Which means reaching farther than your old man did, leaping farther.
